5JsWmwL9FgG5In9c0OLgJQ.text: not good mexican food.  soggy chips, bland flavor.

qIPIaWVzUb_8TtMARigWwg.text: As far as service goes it's consistently some of the best I've found in Singapore. The food is always good, maybe not amazing but but I've always been greeted with a smile, received my food quickly and been checked on to make sure things were to my liking. The waiters are always friendly and the prices aren't bad for the location. If you're looking for a solid laid back Mexican place, this is a great option. Ask for Jessy, she's the best!!

xI805bmi-rFbm-WPzThC_g.text: Bottomless chips and salsa, no extra charges (ie wet napkins and nuts you don't necessarily want), relatively fast service, and the ability to split a check are pretty clear indicators this is in fact owned/operated by Americans. So all of the aforementioned made the dining experience quite nice.As far as the food goes it's all pretty OKAY. I tried the shredded beef burrito, red snapper burrito, quesadillas, nachos, and churros. Everything was a pretty good rendition of what I'm used to back home in Texas, but nothing really could compare to even middle of the road tex-mex places. However based upon the standard of Mexican food in Singapore, it's not bad. The drinks were pretty weak though, I could barely taste the tequila.This restaurant is really over priced though. Expect to spend around $30-45 a head for just an entree and not much more. Overall I wouldn't mind going again, but the pricing and food isn't overall good enough to make this a regular spot for me.

uDpaV471EJDI2i7NzRHrHw.text: It's not easy to find good Mexican food in Singapore, especially at a wallet-friendly price. Sadly, this place doesn't come cheap either but the food is not too bad. At night the place is crowded with chatter and an alfresco dining concept. I had the chicken chimichanga which is sort of like a fried burrito, which was not bad, but nothing to shout about. Portions are huge, so bringing an appetite is a must. Overall I might come back here again for a Mexican fix, but only because there's not many other good Mexican places.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

dBPETT62-mBbIvpZli_Q9A.text: I don't know my drinks very well so this review will be more about the food and atmosphere. You can definitely tell it is a Mexican restaurant as soon as you step close to the greeter podium - the Latin music that gets your feet doing a little dance and the Mother of Mary statue standing tall just behind the cashier. The menu is pretty typical Mexican food - burritos, fajitas and they have free flow of chips and salsa! Gotta love that chips and salsa since that is pretty rare to come across in Singapore. I ordered a plate of green chili stew. My first impression - is this what we ordered? If you are used to the more traditional green chili stew, this dish will not live up to your expectations. It DOES NOT look or taste anything like green chili stew AT ALL. BUT, I do have to give them a thumbs up for that dish because it was a pretty flavorful stew. It tasted more like a meat and potato stew with Mexican spices. The stew came with salted steamed black beans and Spanish rice. They also served it with a side of two tortilla. I would definitely get this dish again on my next visit. You just have to not expect the traditional way here. Go adventure!

0pD1grbTxax9-PzXRF5y7w.text: Have always been a fan of this place. I first came here like 3-4 years ago-ish and fell in love with it then. There weren't seats by the riverside then. But it was (and still is) very festive and authentic. Plus, I didn't know of any other Mexican restaurants in Singapore - so it was quite the routine - to go there and have a jug of margaritas (to share, or, er... not) and Mexican fare.What I Love: They have great drinks. Their margarita flavors are pretty cool. A jug is $57 from 8-11pm. But if you get one after, it's like $39 or something? Which is quite a deal actually. I like that they have half-price and Post Happy Hour prices. They have a pretty cool comprehensive menu detailing their Half-Price discounts. I LOVE their menu - its comprehensive, easy to read and clear. Their drinks and tequila menu is pretty great too. Have tried their Quesadillas, Fajitas, Tortillas, and other stuff that's pretty darn good. Try and explore the menu!What I Don't Love: Their prices. Can get pretty steep. Good to share.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

t6uCYRmjoZk4NmgpAqD_3A.text: Might have taken a munch or two out of my friend's food but I don't recall ordering my own. Their food - Don't think its as good as Chipotle, one can only pray that they will move to Singapore, or Margaritas @Dempsey but definitely better than Tacco Bell... but this place is great for drink and chips (free flow). I would recommend 1. Margaritas (might be bias towards this)2. Chips & SalsaTips: Happy hour! 1. Before 8pm, drinks are priced cheaper. 2. After 11 pm drinks are 30 - 40% off. The place can get super crowded on the weekends and they use to not take reservations but now I see a widget for it so maybe they finally have decided to embrace technology! hurray!

zrr5DnIufKLJ050TToe52A.text: This is as close to Real Tex Mex  as I have found in Singapore after being here 6 years. The location is nice near the river at Clarke Quay. I always order the tacos either fish or chicken and both are excellent. They give you three large tacos, too much for one person plus rice and black beans. The Mexican rice is quite authentic and the beans have a good flavor with a hint of lime. Surprisingly they give free chips and salsa and free refills in soft drinks ( not common in SG). The salsa has a bit of smokey chipotle flavor and decent chips. For those that have posted that the chips were soggy, mine have always come crisp but with Singapore humidity it doesn't take long for them to soften up. The tacos are around $25 but there is enough food for two. I do recommend it as my favorite place for Mexican food in Singapore.

CpM7lM6o7gLDGEp5InlR7w.text: As good a Mexican as you can get in Singapore. Iguana is consistent and of good quality, not cheap but they don't have a service charge. We are multiple repeat customers. Had to post a positive comment after two negative ones today on other Mexican restaurants here.

lvsl2uytsU9dSYQ-o8ATtA.text: Had dinner with 8 ppl last night, it was sunday nite, thiught it'd empty, but i was wrong. Had to wait 25 mins coz its full! But the food here always good, big portion too. Margharita was nice too. Fajitas was nice, chimichangga was big and good! Great place to spend easy dinner with ur mates!

pta5Nv_w0sj1pgUs9jiW3Q.text: I've been coming here for years since the days when we had a fairly boring F&B scene and the Brewerkz/Iguana combo was magical and new.I still come here from time to time when I want straight up decent margaritas or other poison spiked with lots of tequila, and snacky food. I no longer come here as much because there are now better places to drink at, and also because it's gotten so popular with tourists it's hard to get a place unless you come very early.Still an oldie but goodie, though.

_iwqnBP6h3L4x31m1ETHZg.text: Cafe Iguana is run by the same folks at Brewerkz, but their specialty over here is Margaritas rather than beer. Their house margaritas pack quite a punch, and you can get them frozen or on the rocks, and there really isn't anything better than sharing a huge glass (really, too much for one person) of frozen margarita with your friends on a balmy night.The food menu here is Mexican, haven't really had the chance to try it, but like Brewerkz, this place also gets crowded on the weeknights.

ZG3elMF5x4G6ixi9CuRsCQ.text: I have been visiting Café Iguana for several years and it is probably the best Mexican you can get in Singapore. The food quality is consistently delicious, and the margaritas have never failed on me. I especially enjoy the steak chimichangas and order them every time I'm there. Unfortunately, this establishment is a little on the pricey side but the service is good with friendly and efficient staff so I don't quite mind at all.

dsGplxibtE9tua6yUbp2gg.text: Amazing fajitas,  great nachos, wonderful margaritas, super tasty churros, and service was superb.

wH8itkY8mSzuV-TvxJCO5w.text: Chips and salsa are served at your table. The salsa has a nice fresh, salty flavor, similar to what's served at Chili's restaurants. The chips are thin and crispy. We ordered the pork green chile with rice and beans to share. The dish that came out did not at all resemble green chile, instead appearing red with a thick, milky consistency. I'm not sure if we got the wrong thing or if they don't have the same impression of what pork green chile is. Nevertheless, we were quite pleased by the spices and hearty flavor of the dish. The side tortillas made nice for wrapping up black beans, rice, and the chile together. The black beans were standard without any special sauce or seasoning. The rice was no longer white, but still very bland in flavor, as is customary in many Mexican restaurants. Overall, the chile was quite good. Along with the chips and sides, this made for a good light two-person lunch. Note that this place has differential margarita pricing throughout the day, so it pays to start first thing in the morning and pass out shortly after noon.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. kiwi Margarita
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. queso fondito
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. salsa

a1XxC4HGagJei54fobDbsQ.text: Don't mind me, I'm only here for the guacCafe Iguana's a really fun place to hang out in big groups--you can get a margarita for yourself, or you can get one of those ginormous ones to share (I'd always wanted one, but eww, disease vector). The salsa and guacamole and chips flow, and so does the conversastion, deep into the night...

B_dfou_D4w-NZDXUCCCGKw.text: Nice mexican Restaurant in Clarke Quay and a serendipitous discovery. I had some really good Fajitas with chicken. If you arrive early enough, try a jug of Margarita with one of the three different flavours, strawberry, lime or ... I think I forgot the last one. Anyways, a really nice venue at the Singapore river.

2sm5RU1iT-9GHy0Sx2NJoQ.text: I'm a Texan and the food itself at Cafe Iguana is somewhere between okay and pretty good -- but by Singapore standards, it's amazing. It was so comforting to have proper tortillas, chips and salsa, guacamole, margaritas (which get outrageously expensive the later they're ordered), cold water, fork and knife, and cloth napkins. Get the jug of margarita for two people; the glasses are tiny and they are a bit weak.

g433Dau1lb-gswDzfbrwyw.text: This place is one of my favourite places to get margaritas in Singapore. I'm not really a fan of Mexican food so I've never really eaten much but their margaritas by the jug are really something you cannot miss when you come here. My friends swear by the Kiwi, Lime and Pink Guava. If you want beer, they do have some selections but you're better off hopping over to Brewerkz just a few doors down (and owned by the same company)

2lJWnJmbGxXkh5XATE59Kw.text: When an American expat needs fajitas, there are only two places to go. Here, and the American Club. Café Iguana does American Mexican well. The margarita's are good albeit a bit on the sweet side. The chips and salsa are very good. The service is strong, in keeping with their management by Brewerkx.  And the food does not disappoint.

lZkXhNtodDtYjU5i34b80g.text: I always get the Borracho Bean Dip here. All of the things I want (rice, beans, cheese, guacamole, pico, veggies, sour cream) in my burrito or taco or whatever without actually having any outer holder like that. Which is too bad, but it works out to be the most economical item on the menu for me, price- and food-wise. You won't find all of those items together in any other app or entree on the menu. Service is also uncommonly pleasant, prompt and mistake-free on a normal evening.

HXgZXhh3zt75L2_00SUMVg.text: We have been on the hunt for some good Mexican food in Singapore for a while - this place is the best yet.  Freshly fried tortilla chips, fresh salsa, and well-seasoned meats make the food here authentic tasting and delicious.  The staff was super friendly and got us a free salsa and chips after watching our 3-year old mow through the first batch.  Prices are pretty standard for this area of town - more expensive than in a lot of other places in Singapore.  Only complaint was they forgot her order, or maybe we didn't order it clearly enough.  It's outside, so keep that in mind - there's no AC.  The smoking section is also right next to the nonsmoking section...

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

226BYsRjF1UxoK1_5qbrOw.text: Happy hour at Cafe Iguana ($40 for a jug of magaritas before 7pm or after 10pm). Waiting for my buddies to arrive, I managed to instagram the moment. Brings us back to our JC days n years ago Pricing of food was rather expensive between 25-40SGD (how did we afford it back then??). Food was so so. Yay:Chips and salsa - free and delicious Guacamole side - quite yums and flavorful Calamari: nicely fried, awesome sauce Quesadilla with chicken $21 - I love melted cheese! Decent fish, nothing wow or meh about it NahChimichangas - dough quite thick, so so stuffing, too much sour cream Pork carnitas tacos - not the pulled pork I expected, but still yummy pork chunks. Taco skin was a fail. 2 out of 3 skins were abandoned Nachos $20 - overloaded with ingredients, must be shared by 4 or more otherwise wont be finished, chips were very thick unlike the free bowl which was nicer and crispier If I will be back it'll be for the happy hour original/peach magaritas (which was beyond sad after it melted in an hour) and the one tiny bowl of chips and salsa. Nice chill out atmosphere along Singapore River at Riverside Point. Don't expect much from service - very crowded so just keep waving to get attention. #happyhour #mexicanfoodinSGismeh #chipsandsalsa #JCfriends #peachmagaritas #drklingeats

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Quesadilla with chicken $21 - decent but forgettable. Love melted cheese!
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Nachos $20. Chips were too thick
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Best deal is happy hour before 7pm or after 10pm. A jug of magaritas, your pick of flavor, at $40!!! Free chips and salsa are great too

Pvss5ewO_hpJ3FHxF4NTBw.text: I was pleasantly surprised with this place. Food options were limited but a good array of choices. Sits on the river with inside and outside dining. Salsa not up to my usual standards (I am picky) but chips were fresh and plentiful. Hand mixed margaritas and they carry Brewerkz craft beer (sister restaurant), and have lively piped in music. I had the chicken chimichangas and they were quite good. Chunky pieces of chicken rather than shredded but that gave it a unique flavor. Staff was very friendly. WillCome again.

XJ_8tddzUGQG0sBL2sjBFw.text: Walked by this place from my hotel. Was very conveniently located. And the outside seating was excellent. The evening view of the riverside bridges and buildings made it a very tranquil environment.I ordered the Mini Chimichanga made with chicken as an appetizer. And for the main course I ordered the chicken fajitas. Everything was served timely and hot. The ingredients were fresh & tasty. I tried three different margaritas. Remand they have so many more selections of them.  Premium margarita was great and cooling.Tried their Patron margaritas with raspberry and the last one was Pink guava. The price was very reasonable. And from 10pm till closing the margaritas are half off their house selection. Can't wait to come here again. Very satisfied and happy!!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Chips and salsa
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Premium margarita
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

xAtgRxYSqi9aLKjPA1rcUA.text: Food is pretty good but it's a touristy area so very overpriced for what it is. Nachos were a large portion and very shareable. Service is beyond terrible. Expect to wait 20-30minutes for someone to seat you, bring you starters, one said she would bring salsa and it never came, it was over 40 minutes before our drinks came. There seemed to be 2 waitresses that disappeared constantly and we couldn't get anyone's attention to help us. Would not come back here again.

ojnDg5whPM16ghQw2csQdA.text: I like it. The food is good, the atmosphere is good. It was pouring when i went in, so sitting outside looking towards the river while raining was nice. I guess it's mexican food as good as it gets in Singapore.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

DYHb3i_1qMfj5Mu5P9wG-g.text: Very good  food and service. Would definitely revisit. Being a vegetarian liked the veg options. However it's not very authentic Mexican food.

OXkHdz07qO-oR6tJi_7MAw.text: With a good selection of Mexican special cocktails and Margaritas, it is not surprising to see that business is booming even on a Tuesday night. The Red Snapper Burritos ($25) made a stunning entrance like a curvy oblong-shaped parcel, only to reveal a luscious interior of fish, borraco beans, Mexican rice and strands of Mozzarella-cheddar melting mid-way. This could be a potentially great dish if the snapper was not too dry. Puerco en Chile Verde ($14) sounded exotic but it striked a nostalgic chord even if you had not experience any Mexican life before. There isn't so much firepower in this spicy pork stew. But being thick and warm, it goes ideally with the toasted tortillas or simply a direct fast track into your mouth. How does having some tequila in your seafood sounds? The Prawn Brochette ($35) is a skewer of roughly 5-6 lime marinated prawns with smoky tequila glaze, served with grilled vegetables on a stick. It has a heady aroma, though the glaze was short of the wild character of liquor. Nonetheless, the Tequila glaze was an instant hit with the 1/2 Chicken ($28) as the toasty caramelized taste emerged from the skin which retained the moisture of the meat.  The standout dish was the Shredded Steak Chimchangas ($25), a golden crispy flour tortilla that is deep-fried to perfection such that it kept the juicy strands of beef warm and comfortable while displaying resilience any sogginess. Drenched in generous amount of sour cream and guacamole, this giant plate of meaty "Popiah" roll is messy but speaks right to your soul. I don't fancy banana desserts but I may have to take back my statement on the Banana Chimichangas ($14) here. Just like the earlier savoury chimichanga, the filling is substituted with bananas, deep fried till the shell turned into a crunchy fritter. Wallop a huge scoop of fragrant and buttery avocado ice cream and you'll get something that is ten times better than any chocolate lava cake or any hot-cold dessert. There is also the Sauteed Kahlua-glazed Bananas ($14) for those who are less keen on deep-fried food. This ain't no flouncy haute style ala minute flambé bananas but a rustic tropical dessert that sits on a rich and decadent sauce. Other selections include a gluten-free Ancho Chile Chocolate Cake ($14) and Churros ($12) but the former two banana desserts are more satisfying for the bucks and calories.Spice-wise, the dishes are tuned to a temperate palette, yet there were moments during the feast when I thought I was eating Indian briyani. No wonder they say that Indian and Mexican cuisine are actually quite similar! In fact, I was told that about 50% of the customers are Indians. Well, there are three different kinds of authentic Mexican hot sauces aplenty of the table for you to adjust the heat to your preference. Both indoors and outdoors seating are non-air-conditioned but I highly recommend the indoors seating if you want to enjoy the food heartily away from any outdoor smoking.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

ypRV-k9vY961tTDbMUWOhw.text: Touristy spot serving barely edible tex-mex.I liked the riverside atmosphere and funky decor - brightly colored paint and images of Frida Kahlo plastered on the wall. However the food really really let me down.I'm convinced that the guy in the kitchen has never had a real burrito in his life. What came out was a dry, chewy flour-filled abomination that barely resembled one. The enchiladas were not much better. They arrived slathered in cheese, but the taste was barely registering on my tongue. I was left clutching the bottle of habanero sauce attempting to add some zing to what was left sitting on my plate.Maybe my expectations are elevated cos of the years living in CA, visiting the local taco stand, and crossing the border into TJ.I'm wondering how this place gets 4 stars... Maybe it's the margaritas talking.

Rxhed9cdtqFgvd0qrNOXNw.text: This trip was my second to Cafe Iguana and my first for dinner. Obviously I thought the first stop warranted a return. The food is pretty darn good, the service is as good (even on a Friday night) and the location and ambiance are first rate - no question the location makes the experience even better. We started with the chips and salsa, ordered some guacamole and had the chimichangas - all were served promptly and the chimichangas (beef) were tasty. I had the chicken fajitas (which arrived sizzling hot and with ample veggies and salsa, guava and sour cream) and my Wife had the beef burrito. All of which were really good (and portions excellent). We had the little ones with us and the staff was also pretty fun with them as well. I'll go back! It's a fun place to spend an evening and you can leave satisfied with your meal!

UPsiga48RTiLcPcv_M37NQ.text: This was awesome! The food was great! Customer service excellent, one of the waiters saw we were struggling with the spice and brought over water and sour cream. Only down side a bit too hot spice wise!

RP7iro9mLFaKxshsrxByqw.text: One of my favorite Mexican restaurants in Singapore. With a great view next to the Singapore river, especially in the evening with a nice breeze, it's a perfect spot for a pitcher of margaritas and some nachos followed up by a great burrito or fajitas. My office is nearby and I have taken several dinner meetings here; always a good meal with decent service (decent is my high rating for service in Singapore)

2-u7u8sE_ZK8R4tFPcaIjQ.text: New menu and none the better. The margaritas are still fantastic and the setting on the Singapore River is lovely, but the food is in steady decline.  We ate on a very quiet Sunday evening. Jumbo, the restaurant next to Cafe Iguana, was packed, but we were one of only a few active tables at Cafe Iguana.The meal started with flavorless and exceptionally cold (a theme for the meal) salsa. The refrigerated salsa tasted like pureed tomatoes with little added to that. Tortilla chips without any salt or flavoring at all on them and the free appetizer seems designed to keep people from wanting seconds.I had the shrimp burrito with the oddly named carne de puerco en chile verde. On the positive side, the pork green chili stew was the best thing on the table all night. Genuinely delicious albeit oddly named as there was absolutely nothing green about it. Very standard reddish brown chili/stew color without any visible green capsicum or anything green.  Sadly, the burrito itself was a huge disappointment... very few shrimp (but those that were there tasted pretty good) mixed with isolated clumps of different ingredients (i.e., so you get several servings of nothing but beans, followed by one serving of nothing but shrimp, etc.) on a tortilla that was mostly raw and topped (after "cooking") with raw (unmelted) cheese (see photo).The kids had the mini tostadas and a quesadilla.  Both were mostly left on the plate.The taco salad did little to resemble a taco or its typical ingredients. Essentially a load of plain lettuce sitting on a pancake flat raw tortilla with a dab of sour creme hidden under the tortilla that my wife didn't even find until after she stopped eating. Only about a third of the salad was eaten.  Finally, service was painfully slow and we had to ask four times to get someone to bring a glass of water. What used to be an almost iconic Mexican restaurant in Singapore has matured into a tired and uninspired disappointment.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore. Shrimp burrito served with lumps of cold (completely unmelted) cheese dumped on top.

EpwyJ12iPSZ7MYIEj6DIWg.text: My wife and I eat here all the time, its consistently good. The fajitas are my personal fav. This with a few IPA and its a great way to spend Sunday afternoon.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore

jAay9RE_miusWXq8bNz_tA.text: Since we only had a few drinks, I cannot provide a fair rating of the place, but I would have been happier if they had more options than one type of each (red, white, rose, sparkling) wine by the glass. However; they had a much more extensive selection of margarithas! They also had complementary nachos with a very tasteful and delicious housemade salsa. I want that recipe!Service was somewhat inattentive, but the staff were smiling and nice. The location by the river is nice, with a view to the loud and stressful bars and clubs on the other side (Clark Quay party street). The athmosphere is laid-back and the interiors are quite simple, but colorful.

u2ilamcUzhyKSYc9yqoEHQ.text: Visiting on business from California. Found a gem for Mexican food in Singapore.Awesome ambiance. Sat at the bar for margaritas and beer. Midoririta was really light so I finished with a black pig. Chicken fajitas were pretty authentic. The habanero sauces helped kick it up a notch. Great place to hang out on a Friday night.

7AHPAUlX9pMWayoF7Rc0MA.text: I had the jalapeño poppers and veggie tacos - both were extremely average. The jalapeño poppers seemed more like a bland capsicum tempura. The bathrooms are terribly small too. Don't recommend!

Q3cdgATtTG10mlgg3F9EFw.text: An easy option if you're seeking Mexican food and Margaritas in the Clarke Quay area. Persistently great atmosphere on evenings. Get there before 7pm to enjoy discounted Marg pitchers!

NwfVFHtxDY4sEnL54vb1zQ.text: Okay, Okay, I know I'm in Asia and I shouldn't be seeking out Mexican food, but after my 18th bowl of noodles, I was ready to switch it up.  Having had decent Mexican food in Hong Kong, I decided to give this place a whirl hoping Singapore would do me well.  Wow, this is quite possibly the worst Mexican food of my life.  Super small portions at outrageous prices.  Yeah, I know I was in the Quay, but still.  The chips were stale, the salsa was mush, the queso tasted like it was out of a can and the tostadas weren't even tostadas.  They were chips with a mound of lettuce on top.  The drinks were abysmal.  Biggest waste of money throughout my trek in Singapore.

xZXB1lC_xjLZ0Kv6LwZzBA.text: I'll just reiterate what others have said: get a few friends and get the giant jug of magarita! It's signature tequila cocktails are also worth a try. It's a great place for either after dinner drinks, or drinks before you hit the rest of the night scenes.If you're more of a beer person, like I am, there are also some beer to choose from.I can't think of anywhere else in Singapore where you can get a Mexican menu as comprehensive as this. Quesadillas, fajitas, tortillas etc. are all aplenty. I also like the grilled prawns on the hotplate thing.The atmosphere of the restaurant is great, and the decor unique. I like that the music isn't too loud so that conversation can flow easily. Definitely a great place to hang out.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Cafe Iguana - Singapore, Singapore
